Caudal: Pubic bones, iliac crest, inguinal ligament
Other: Digitations at the level of the diaphragm
Lower intercostal, iliohypogastric, and ilioinguinal nerves (roots T7-T11)
Just below the rib cage, aligned with the anterior superior iliac spine
At the midpoint of a line connecting the anterior superior iliac spine and the lower border of the rib cage at the mid-axillary line
Intersection of the horizontal line through the umbilicus and the vertical line through the axillary fold

vues.title: Transverse View
objectifs: Static observation of the transversus abdominis muscle
Dynamic visualization of transversus abdominis muscle contraction: biofeedback
parametres: Note: These parameters will differ according to the subject's physique (particularly depth). Although this is always the case, the variability observed for the abdominal region will be even more significant, particularly in obese or pregnant subjects, etc.
positionnement: Note: It is recommended to start by locating the rectus abdominis muscle and surrounding structures, as described in the rectus abdominis protocol
Position 1: Place the probe in longitudinal view at the level of the intertubercular groove
Position 2: Move the probe slightly laterally to locate the transversus abdominis (so that it occupies a larger portion of the image)

Position 3: Perform a slight rotation of the probe to align it with the fibers of the transversus abdominis. Depending on the craniocaudal positioning of the probe, the rotation may be more or less significant. A simple visual reference can be to align the medial side of the probe toward the umbilicus (for approximate orientation)

imagePositionnement.descriptionText: Starting position of the probe, at the level of the linea semilunaris
Probe moved laterally to better visualize the transversus abdominis muscle
Rotation of the probe to align with the fibers of the transversus abdominis

texte: Subcutaneous fat can be observed in the upper portion of the image as a thick hypoechoic layer without particular tissue organization

The rectus abdominis muscle is located on the right side of the image, beneath the subcutaneous fat. This muscle appears as a slightly hyperechoic rounded area, bordered deeply by a strongly hyperechoic fascia

The external oblique muscle, a slightly hyperechoic linear area, appears on the left side of the image, just beneath the subcutaneous fat. It is recognized as being the most superficial, and one can appreciate the clearly defined fascia surrounding it
The internal oblique muscle appears as a thick area just deep to the external oblique, whose medial border (on the right of the image) is adjacent to the linea semilunaris
The transversus abdominis muscle is the deepest muscle on this image, just beneath the internal oblique. When the probe is positioned this way, it appears quite similar to the external oblique
The linea semilunaris is the structure that separates the rectus abdominis muscle from the internal oblique in the center of the image, and can be described as a narrow triangular hyperechoic area

identification.title: [Position 2: Probe moved laterally, above the transversus abdominis]

texte: The external oblique muscle is present in the upper left part of the image and can be described as a fusiform hyperechoic area
The internal oblique muscle is again located beneath the external oblique and appears as a thick, slightly wavy rectangular hyperechoic area
The transversus abdominis muscle appears once again as a thin hyperechoic linear area, deep to the internal oblique muscle

text: The transversus abdominis is the deepest of the lateral abdominal muscles. It forms a broad muscular sheet that wraps around the abdomen, with fibers running horizontally from the thoracolumbar fascia to the linea alba.

This muscle is unique in its continuous arrangement around the abdomen, forming a natural 'corset' that provides stability to the trunk and assists in controlling intra-abdominal pressure. Its fibers are arranged in a transverse direction, unlike the oblique orientation of the internal and external oblique muscles.
The muscle has extensive attachments, including:

• Superiorly: to the inner surface of the lower six costal cartilages, interdigitating with the diaphragm
  • Posteriorly: to the thoracolumbar fascia
  • Inferiorly: to the iliac crest and lateral third of the inguinal ligament

The muscle's aponeurosis contributes to the posterior and anterior rectus sheaths, ultimately joining with the contralateral muscle at the linea alba. This arrangement is crucial for maintaining abdominal wall integrity and function.

content.subtitle: Core Stability
text: The transversus abdominis plays a crucial role in core stability:

• Contributes to spinal stabilization through increased intra-abdominal pressure
  • Acts as part of the deep core muscle system
  • Important in both static and dynamic postural control

content.subtitle: Low Back Pain
text: The muscle's function is often altered in low back pain:

• Delayed activation in patients with chronic low back pain
  • Reduced thickness and altered recruitment patterns
  • Important target for rehabilitation exercises

content.subtitle: Pregnancy and Postpartum
text: The transversus abdominis is particularly relevant in obstetric contexts:

• Undergoes significant changes during pregnancy
  • Important in postpartum recovery
  • Can be affected in diastasis recti
